column1: Will legal restrictions on the number of people who can meet indoors be imposed in England before 1 January 2022?
column6: ['Society', 'Health', 'Non-US Politics']
https://lfpress.com/news/local-news/omicron-moving-quicker-than-we-can-identify-cases-londons-top-doctor
https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/omicron-variant-coronavirus-news-12-20-21-intl/h_45e2ee39dc8e898efdb9b154da005837
Latest numbers are high again, deaths up

@belikewater Just when you thought the drama was fading :) Despite the high numbers it looks like New Year in England will go ahead unrestricted, however I just noticed that the question only closes on 1st January 2022 - now to my understanding of things the question always closes before time, so does this then mean that if restrictions were put into place on 1st of January 2022 it would count as a 100% yes - - or will they only spring into action on Monday --- or Will Boris be under pressure to close the taps, if so he have to make some form of gestures between now and tomorrow, will have to keep an eye on No 10
edging back a bit
After seeing today's numbers one wonders if Boris is going to have to fold

Just take a look inside "Alley Palley" where the Darts World Championship are taking place and you know what's going on - and legal restrictions are not going to happen any time soon. The Health England admin apparently has the strategy of acquiring natural herd immunity.
UK reports record new Covid-19 cases after Johnson rules out restrictions https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/458749/uk-reports-record-new-covid-19-cases-after-johnson-rules-out-restrictions
http://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-no-more-coronavirus-restrictions-in-england-before-new-year-sajid-javid-confirms-12504748
No new Covid rules in England before new year - Javid https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-59804686

Interesting thread on hospitalizations in London and the UK: https://twitter.com/ChrisCEOHopson/status/1475540046677790723 Also, supposedly PCR tests not easily available in UK right now: https://twitter.com/DDurwent/status/1475478267134099463
The UK has shown its various colours. In England, common sense is dead and the political survival of one man rules supreme above everything and everyone else.
based on statements reported in the news, shared by @belikewater @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1374056 and others.
In case they change their minds.

BBC Breaking News: "There will be no further Covid restrictions in England before the new year, UK Health Secretary Sajid Javid says, but he urges people to "remain cautious"" https://twitter.com/BBCBreaking/status/1475509168362737664 @Anneinak
Woohoo
Just confirmed no new restrictions before end of year. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/dec/27/boris-johnson-will-impose-no-further-covid-restrictions-before-new-year

The Government have indicated that they do not intend to impose new restrictions until after New Year. However, a U-turn based on new data or public opinion is not entirely impossible and therefore there is still a non-zero chance of restrictions being imposed.
h/t @DCorrado
Looks like I got this one wrong. I thought the hospitalisation admissions data would be the key metric, but BJâ€™s lack of political capital turned out to be more important.

I had planned to drop around 3% per day until the new year, but I am jumping the gun on the back of this: BBC News - No new Covid rules in England before new year - Javid https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-59804686

London admissions for the 27th at 364. 1171 UK wide despite cases into the 130k range. It doesn't feel like a peak yet, but nothing about Omicron seems easy to predict at this point, so maybe?... Unless something drastic happens in the next couple days it's looking like this is a no.

As mentioned previously, the less days left, the lower the chance of the government getting anything done. New data should be presented to PM but it seems he is unlikely to make any moves in response (see here: The Guardian: Boris Johnson not expected to announce more Covid restrictions. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/dec/27/cabinet-ministers-sceptical-of-stricter-covid-curbs-in-england )
Should know by either later tonight or tomorrow, all rather like the Mock Turtle from Alice in Wonderland singing Will you won't you

Down 10 on this article and info about political opposition to lockdowns provided by others. This article suggests a meeting has happened and is unlikely to result in new restrictions, but it seems a bit too rumor-ish to put too much weight on.

Parliament recall process needs to start tomorrow for this to resolve as 'yes': - 48 hours to recall parliament - Restrictions so far have gone into place at '1 minute past midnight', e.g 28th recall, 30th vote, restrictions start at 1 minute past midnight on 31st
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-59792754 Almost thought this question was resolved, only to realize that the question only talks about England and not UK.

I have been wondering if public opinion in England has changed and if people will now demand government action. Well, it seems not! check out the research shared by @ctsats @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1373582
There's been nothing from https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/ for two days now, wonder were they gone, will they be back on Monday? Next year?

In a rather new twist, The Guardian reports (Dec 25, https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/dec/25/now-tory-mps-warn-dont-toughen-covid-new-year-rules ): --------------- Tory MPs warn Boris Johnsonâ€™s rivals to oppose tougher Covid new year rules
No comments today on numbers. If there is no comments tomorrow I'll be very close to 0.

Data coming out on Monday. Might have peaked in London, but if still increasing outside there may be restrictions in other cities in England so answer is yes for those areas meeting the criteria for the question.

"Around 1 in 20 Londoners likely had Covid-19 on Dec. 16 and early estimates - which could yet be revised - suggest this may have risen to 1 in 10 on Sunday, models from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed on Friday. The ONS estimates showed around 1 in 35 people in England - equivalent to 1.54 million people - were infected with Covid-19 during the six days to Dec. 19. The early modelling of the subsequent days suggested that could have risen to more than 2 million people on Sunday, or around 1 in 25. Many industries and transport networks are struggling with staff shortages as sick workers self-isolate, while hospitals in Britain have warned of the risk of an impact on patient safety." https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/25/uk-sets-new-record-for-covid-cases-as-omicron-sweeps-london.html

Media narrative is omicron less severe- causes 'mild' symptoms. Ministers and backbenchers believe public wont accept restrictions -some yougov polling to back this up. restrictions less likely to be effective the later they're put in and damage is the same. However growth rate could still see hospitals overwhelmed and pictures of this on TV may force government to reimpose restrictions. Money already given to devolved nations and hospitality. restrictions put in other nations. boosters will hopefully take effect in other regions of UK before hospitals overwhelmed. may close nightclubs.

Modeling shows a clear benefit to earlier restrictions (https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1043854/S1463_Warwick_Omicron_Modelling.pdf), gov. has suggested a decision taking effect 12/28, unclear whether restrictions will come earlier than 1/1 but seems more likely than not.
Politics wins over science.
@belikewater has written the most comprehensive analysis yet, here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1372668

I think the powers that be and their behind the scenes scientific advisors are monitoring many different numbers to determine whether restrictions should be imposed next week. One stated threshold they're looking at is 400 hospital admissions/day in London. See https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1371608

My guess is ppl don't want to be sick over the hols, so having read that the Wolf at the door is a little bit more conciliaTORY this year (excuse the palindrome) they might well tell the bug to beetle off and rather get back to watching the Beatles on the box, unless of course the kids are playing up downstairs, so maybe a bit of Lennon's Isol will do the trick, Walter Raleigh and all that. But no need to go down the Old Nag
Leaning a bit toward less likely as there hasn't been any news about it yet.

Down a little with the heavy spin in UK media of less severe infection. Whilst this makes little difference to the health and economic stresses that would in normal times be a driver for circuit breaker restrictions, this may represent an attempt to move the public opinion away from lockdowns at all as unnecessary to the preservation of life.

I'm confused. I do think London hospital admissions will likely go up to 400/day over the next few days. But at the same time, it appears that London cases may already have peaked (although I'm not completely sure whether they haven't just had a dip related to the days of the week). London is obviously being used as the canary in the coal mine for the rest of England. But if hospital admissions just briefly go up to 400/day or a bit over and then fall, I'm not sure BJ will find it worth it to recall Parliament to sit on Dec 28 and battle to issue restrictions.
Projecting hospital admissions to go up to 400/day over the next few days.

Aha. Found the London hospitalizations page that shows admissions: https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/healthcare?areaType=nhsRegion%26areaName=London 307 admissions on Dec 21, and it still seems to be a growth trend. There will be no official updates on the website on Dec 25 and 26.

According to this article [1] there's supposedly a threshold of 400 hospitalizations a day that might trigger new measures. [2] Shows hospitalizations on the rise. I'm not sure if that threshold will be hit and restrictions imposed, seems kind of like a tossup right now.

Coming down a bit (and increasing the political push back weighting) with the release of the new report into Omicron (being spun heavily in gov friendly media on the â€˜less severe so suck it upâ€™ angle).
More rumors of restrictions to be imposed around Dec 27: https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-10334091/New-Years-parties-banned-Boris-Johnson-plans-new-Covid-crackdown-48-hours.html
But hospitalizations.

Restrictions will start on Dec 26 in Wales: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/boris-johnson-mark-drakeford-wales-england-sajid-javid-b1980823.html And plenty of rumors circulating of restrictions to be imposed in England on Boxing Day as well.

Bringing likelihood back down as it does look like government need to be recalled. But not by much Iâ€™m guessing there are still mechanisms for parliament to meet remotely, which means physical travel is not needed.

Given up on this! One hand Johnson doesn't have support of his cabinet (already lost Frost to Plan B) and would need to recall parliament that would be humiliating as backbenchers vent for hours on end. ICU numbers not at the required threshold it seems. The reasons for yes are that public already been softened for further restrictions and are generally supportive.
Reduced based on the reported 400 hospital omissions theory
Think the tide is turning quickly against severity or perceived severity. I think we are not most likely not going to see restrictions introduced this year but still volatile.

A discussion of some of the criteria for restrictions that are supposedly being considered: https://inews.co.uk/news/politics/new-restrictions-england-avoided-hospital-admissions-london-do-not-soar-this-week-1364554 "Fresh restrictions in England after Christmas could be avoided if hospital admissions in London stay below 400 a day by the end of this week" "While the figure of 400 is not a hard and fast threshold, it will provide a good guide of whether the huge scale of Omicron cases, above 80,000 in England for the past week, will translate into hospital admissions and put severe pressure on the NHS throughout January. If London admissions remain below 400, it could mean no legally enforced restrictions are needed after Christmas, although there could be tougher guidance announced by the Prime Minister on 27 December. Hospital admissions in London are not the only metric being used to assess the severity of Omicron, but is a key measure. Separately, the UK Health Security Agency will produce early data on severity, analysing vaccination status and age of people admitted to hospital with the Omicron variant, which is also expected before Christmas Eve. However the situation is still fluid, and ministers stress that all options remain in reserve if hospitals come under serious pressure over the New Year." "But some boroughs are continuing to show the highest case rates of the pandemic for younger age groups, with one in 16 people aged 25 to 29 testing positive in the week to 16 December" [and younger adults are less likely to be hospitalized.]

I'm stopping here. Leaving 15% in the tank to account for the political drag factor for this question, but in every other regard the mood music on the street and in the media seems to be preparing the population for the inevitable "decision" straight after Christmas.
Wales, Scotland and many EU countries are starting to tighten up. It definitely gives a route out of any reluctance in government.

As at 12:16hrs, 22nd December 21: the Welsh Government have just announced restrictions that would resolve this question as yes that appear to legally come into force (under devolved administration rules) as of the 26th December 21 (boxing day) [1].
Coming down 5% to more fully take account of the political influences that are in play.
I still feel that I'm being conservative here but it's a big adjustment fro my 20%. Hard to say if they'll be legal or not.
Down due to forecasts by @jleibowich and @Scappleby
I found a more trusted source of the rumor that Step 2 restrictions may be imposed after Christmas: https://twitter.com/PippaCrerar/status/1472933272598499331 @Anneinak

It won't happen before Christmas: https://twitter.com/BloombergUK/status/1473346503422971908 I feel like whether they're going to impose restrictions is right on the knife's edge.... I think that imposing restrictions between Christmas and New Year's would also require calling Parliament back to do so. (I'm not completely sure whether that's the only way, but that's what I've read.) But, I see rumors of returning to Step 2 restrictions on Dec. 27. They are only rumors and are not from trusted sources. @Anneinak

Great discussion all around. It seems there's a metric ton of pressure going both ways on this one but the weight is to the conservatives opposing at the current moment (but that could change in an instant). I suspect their argument will be that hospitalizations are still stable and that's what matters. Without a noticeable increase in admissions the NHS is going to struggle to make their case to hard liners. It's hard to say if the Dec 26th rumours are scare tactics or to mentally prepare the populace. It's likely a mess either way.

Noting that a lot of the crowd are increasing their estimates quite substantially. I am debating myself a lot on this one: Previously I said I would sit at 25 until cabinet meetings were called. But... On the one hand, as the number of days left until the deadline dwindle, surely the probability should be decreasing - on the simple logic that there's days to get done what would need to be done (recall parliament, agree measures, etc) On the other hand, on Johnson's wording today I would increase the probability ( "we can't rule out any further measures after Christmas"- https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-59747966 )

Confirmed nothing before Christmas. I think direction of the mood right now is ebbing away from legal restrictions, but it probably needs to gather a bit more momentum before this becomes less than 50% again.
No legal restrictions before Christmas confirmed.
Increasingly convinced some kind of restrictions will be imposed on either the 27th or 28th December.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-59733893
Nts: Holz 3744

Even with uncertainty with legality, I think most times this would resolve as a legal measure and it seems that is the plan between now and the new year. My forecast lies between the crowd median and the consensus of those updating their forecasts spectacularly in order to respect continuity and personal uncertainty about understanding England's politics, political rationality, and question resolution criteria. This forecast leans a bit more to the frequent updaters here and I nudge it closer to them because of my naturally conservative percentages.

Bringing this down a little again on the basis that the meeting today didn't result in immediate restrictions, and now unlikely restrictions will be in place in time for Christmas (48 hours to recall parliament, means that earliest this could be passed would be the 23rd, and it certainly looks unlikely that the trigger will be pulled tomorrow).

It sounds like restrictions are coming but what type will they be? I think that it could be difficult to tell if they are legal restrictions or not does this require an act of parliament to be passed? does that require parliament to be recalled from recess? Can they just do it within the caucus and have it be legal under the health act?. I don't think that schools will be legal restrictions - more operational so I am not counting on them resolving the question yes. I suspect that there could be situations where they restrict 'types' of people rather than 'numbers' of people. ie all unvaccinated people must stay at home and accept no visitors but those who have got their booster (which they have offered to every person in UK) can have less restricted access to things. In this case the number of people hasn't been restricted to vaccinated households. It will be interesting to see how GJO interprets curfews if they are put in place. In my own judgement (anticipating GJOs response to anyone's question on this...) I think that they are not restricting the number of people just the timing that those people can mix so I don't think they should count.

It seems likely that some sort of restrictions, lockdown or curfew will be announced on Dec. 26 and implemented soon thereafter, although things could happen before Christmas, too. "Just had a call in. There will be a circuit breaker lockdown after Christmas pending further data. I am waiting on further information." https://twitter.com/UKActionteam/status/1472972539957764096 "The Government will not make an announcement on a rumoured lockdown to limit the spread of Omicron until Boxing Day, reports have claimed. Dec 26 has been earmarked as D-Day for further restrictions, according to a report." Link to news article here: https://twitter.com/Gab_H_R/status/1472620240232226823 "The Government will not make an announcement on a rumoured lockdown to limit the spread of the Omicron variant of Covid-19 until Boxing Day, reports have claimed. December 26 has been earmarked as D-Day for further restrictions, according to a report by the Sunday Times this weekend. Leaks to the paper suggest the Government will move fast as soon as Christmas is over to bring in tougher measures to control the virus. However, Health Secretary Sajid Javid also refused to rule out bringing in additional curbs on freedoms before Christmas. Speaking on the final ever episode of The Andrew Marr Show on BBC One, Mr Javid said the pandemic had made it clear decision makers could give no guarantees. When it was suggested to him he was not ruling out a circuit-breaker or new restrictions before Christmas, Mr Javid said: â€œThere are no guarantees in this pandemic, I donâ€™t think. At this point we just have to keep everything under review.â€" @Anneinak
Still have the feeling it is going to be Christmas OK and the door closes on New Year, all depends on the numbers, with 11 days to go - very difficult
I have requested 3 clarifications.

Boris Johnsonâ€™s latest statement seems to indicate the current stance is defined by political constraints (though described in terms that suggest the government still feels the need to wait to review data further).
Rumours among journalists that social limits on indoor will be implemented on 27th December. Whether they will be made law or strong advice is yet to be seen.
Back down after today. I think guidance is the next step, but a decent chance pubs and clubs will face restrictions before NYE.
it appears the most likely way this question resolves "yes" is a restriction put in place just before New Years (but not before Boxing Day)

Down 10 after reading this article. Seems there are a lot of hurdles that would be involved in implementing measures prior to the end of the year. The biggest seem to be that parliament would have to be called back from recess and there is resistance in Johnson's party to the idea of new lockdowns. https://www.thenational.scot/news/19797239.omicron-boris-johnson-considering-step-2-covid-restrictions-next-week/

Sounds like it's definitely on the table in the Christmas to New Year's window but not before as of right now. I don't know that they'll follow through with this though. https://www.leaderlive.co.uk/news/19797283.step-2-covid-restrictions-boris-johnson-considering-new-rules-next-week/
More rumours on this appearing now, from a cabinet meeting which is presumably still happening.
Swinging now that the government have changed their tune regarding the possibility. "No guarantees" makes it a lot more likely now ðŸ˜…
Omniron will probably give the politicians in England another chance to impose lock downs on Holiday social gatherings.

The big driver for some sort of circuit breaker now appears to be the impact on NHS staff requiring self isolation at an already fragile time for the UK health service (and regional services in particular) [1].
I think I will sit here until any cabinet meeting is called. There seems to be a few rumblings, but hard to decipher how much is noise.

More rumblings this morning on this topic https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-59716357?ns_mchannel=social&ns_source=twitter&ns_campaign=bbc_live&ns_linkname=61bee35c99991e76caa3060a%26%27It%20may%20be%20too%20late%20to%20react%27%20-%20Sajid%20Javid%262021-12-19T08%3A19%3A30.182Z&ns_fee=0&pinned_post_locator=urn:asset:a1d7b3fa-14ee-43dc-a3a1-fa7c95668082&pinned_post_asset_id=61bee35c99991e76caa3060a&pinned_post_type=share.
Jumping up a bit more on @kevins Times link Seems very likely that this should be pushed through and that it could be the end of the PM also

I am trying to decide from scratch what my probability should be. If I wasn't gambling to get my brier score better, if I wasn't trying bring in what I would chose to do, if I wasn't trying to chose what is best for the population. Ned just locked down, Scotland has increased restrictions, France is increasing restrictions, UK just did some but too little too late and it nearly broke the govt... I would give a >50 probability that 4 more euro countries will lock down before the end of the year but I am struggling to make this prediction. If it goes yes my brier score is stuffed anyway, if it goes no then I want to optimise my score. I think I am going to have to increase.
Average of 2 of my guesses.

I have been holding this down for too long under the situation. The PM is going to have to call an emergency cabinet meeting to discuss further measures eg rule of 6 or 3 families like Scotland has. The other thing that I am considering is that Scotlands rules are guidelines not legal restrictions. It is only time til question end that is holding me down and I feel that I am going to take a big hit on this question (under 10% since August 21)
Recent news. BoJo is panicking again. I am going back up. Likely to be started post Christmas. My 20% is if it starts New Years day.
Starting to unravel

Adjusting up, I agree with what others have posted on circuit breaker being considered, but also I am dragging a little, they are trying to very seriously encourage people over mandating anything, also now they would have bring them back from vacation.
Up 15 on the potential "circuit breaker" plans, though Johnson seems opposed at the moment.
As I recall, parsley rosemary and the other one
Ramping this back up once again on the news... https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/8b5d83f0-5f91-11ec-8fac-c70e630faee6?shareToken=67b65a618a6bd59ec1652fd399a1d921
Manchester centre was a shadow of itself last night. We went in three usually popular places - they were all at half capacity.

After the rebellion in the Conservative Party last Tuesday, and with the parliament on Christmas holidays from Dec 16 to Jan 5 (https://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-commons-faqs/business-faq-page/recess-dates/ ), I think it is highly unlikely.
Drop by 2 due to current sentiment and difficulty of getting a difficult thing passed before 1st planning is for boosters to quickly drop the curve
Slight adjustment down on Boris' comments today.

Bringing this back down significantly on the basis that the idea of further restrictions seems to be getting abandoned in favour of guidance. I think if this is going to resolve as yes it will be after Christmas, and only if the current wave is still accellerating. Chris Whitty talking about data that become available between xmas and new year being used to determine this (https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-big-numbers-of-coronavirus-patients-in-hospital-after-christmas-due-to-phenomenal-omicron-spread-warns-whitty-12496558). If infections rise at the current pace though it will all be over by then. I think the guidance to reduce socialising will be quite effective as people are desperate to avoid isolation over Christmas.
PM's announcement not as big as I had thought, however restrictions could still be put in place before the new year
Down 15 after Johnson's announcement, sounds like he said no further restrictions and just urged caution.

I still think they will put off restrictions until the new year, if they introduce them at all, because Iâ€™m not sure people will accept that kind of restriction again. But I have to up the probability somewhat to recognise the situation

Will hold, think any household indoor restrictions will only be advisory before Jan 1. Pubs and clubs at risk, but backbenchers will not tolerate this, and Johnson's position I believe would become untenable (unless covid deaths absolutley massive relative)
Happy to adjust up to proportionally match the wisdom of the crowd but I think the likelihood is being overstated still.
Hospital and deaths will be the factor in the next 16 days
Up 20% for now on the news of a COVID related announcement today.
A major announcement is expected this evening, I have reason to believe that there will be large restrictions announced, which may include the number of people that can meet indoors.

Probably with yesterday's move to implement a covid passport type approach they will feel they have done enough for now, they will likely wait at least 1 or 2 weeks to see what the results start looking like and so I think any further changes in approach are likely post Christmas and probably past the deadline

Johnsons drumming today and threats from his previously friendly media outlets are likely to have a significant impact on the Clown Princes spinal integrity and gumption to put in further restrictions.
Omicron and the short timeline is making me twitchy Scotland has put out new guidelines but they are not 'legal restrictions' nor is it England
OK cancel that... it is not England and they are not legal restrictions. Moral of the story is: read first, forecast later

Dropping down from yesterday's considerable jump up due to the continued pressure that the PM is under from his own party. He was only just able to get plan b through the house because the opposition voted for it. 90 of his own party voted against calling it a slippery slop towards authoritarian rule. Seems a bit dramatic to me but alas that is politics.

There's considerable resistance of MPs of the whole party spectrum against measures of the "Plan B" package such as the Covid-Pass and mask mandates (and which does not contain legal restrictions on meetings in person) as well as concern about the financial impact on the "hospitality industry" in its most important season and thus push to "save christmas this year". Most MPs welcome and support milder interventions such as lateral flow-test requirements and improvements in resources etc that promise to accelerate the booster jab campaign.

Noted that Scotland are assertively suggesting some limits but they are not making them legal requirements. I think that is the likely next step for England, which might not leave the time to pass and impose legal restrictions.

Not certain but 20% seems too low now. The push and focus on booster vaccines is likely the first line of defense and probably pushes any action off until the new year. There doesn't seem to be the political will to impose restrictions until that option is no longer effective...
Johnson appears to be laying the groundwork for additional COVID measures ahead of what appears to be an imminent health service collapse (at best at a regional level).
30% for what is needed and 70% on what I think will happen feels like a good split right now. Maybe I should be higher as Scotland may put their own rules in place. The daily increase is incredible
The virus' transmissibility is very concerning. But any new restrictions would have to pass Parliament first, which could take half a week at least. That would leave two weeks to the end of the year.
As the UK approaches 50% of its COVID cases being Omicron, divided politicians may use that as the motivating trigger to reinstate such a restriction.
Moving up with announcements in Scotland and restrictions on numbers being placed on care home visitors (out of bounds for this question but potentially a sign of things to come).

Upping significantly based on yesterdayâ€™s technical briefing. https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1040076/Technical_Briefing_31.pdf. Data on transmission and 2 dose immunity is bad news. NHS bed capacity at similar levels to December 2020. Plan B unlikely to have a big enough impact on hospitalisations.
Will be interesting to see the size of Tory rebellion on Tuesday

Increasing my forecast for this significantly because of the volatility of the situation right now. In my previous forecast I said measures would only be re introduced if the variant was vaccine evasive and caused more severe disease as well as being highly transmissible. However I didnâ€™t account for it being quite as highly transmissible. We are now seeing doubling times of maybe even less than 2 days. It might be the case that restrictions are brought in as a precaution before hospital data are seen, since waiting for that data could be catastrophic. On balance I now think this is very likely since by the end of next weekend we could see 40k Omicron cases per day, and growing. The pressure will be too much to not introduce at least some restrictions on numbers meeting indoors in an effort to buy time to see what hospitalisation data look like.
Think there's a few "asymmetric" and less obvious ways this may resolve as a yes that are worth considering.

Govt has been advised to restrict further to reduce transmission of O according to documents leaked to the Guardian https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/dec/10/stringent-uk-covid-measures-needed-within-a-week-leak-reveals Comes down to a toss up between locking down to save lives or saving Christmas to save political careers Have jumped up from 6 to 18% as Omicron is growing at the worst predictions.
Revised as per Plan B announced today so less likely more restrictions after Xmas.
https://www.bbc.com/news/explainers-52530518
Plan B being announced today. I am going up to 98 as I think that we will be looking at rule of 6 type restrictions
Adjusting down with @SE_Meyer s pertinent point about the political / populist reaction to the Xmas Party disclosures.

Worth a read from Professor Neil Ferguson, head of the Department of Infectious Disease Epidemiology at Imperial College London and a member of the Governmentâ€™s Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage):

Up a couple with Plan B, time is getting seriously tight though, and even the measures last week that included mask wearing on public transport was opposed by dozens of Tory MPs. Johnson is perhaps starting in his head to count leadership letters to 1922 committee, he simply cannot afford to further provoke his backbenchers at this stage.
Way things are going at the moment if they announced serious restrictions you might see riots, but plan B is Go

Omicron's transmissibility is high but the severity of illness, seemingly, is much more mild. So mild that it decreases the already-projected strain on the NHS? I'm not clever enough to know that and I'm not sure SAGE has concluded anything.

The government shifting position is potentially more impactful than the actual shift to Plan B as it shows they are willing to make impositions on peoples freedoms over Christmas that many here believed the Libertarian wing of the Tory Party and populist playbook in Johnson's hands simply would not permit.

It looks like they will be implementing Plan B rules today - but the plan has no limits on numbers of people - and I think this will feel like enough is being done for now so they will not introduce anything more severe until after Christmas.

The autumn 2020 lockdowns demonstrated that the tipping point for reintroducing restrictions is not not the number of deaths or cases but hospitalisations. Daily hospital admissions in England are now at a similar level to this time last year (19/10/21: 799 compared to 19/10/20: 773 - rolling 7 day average). Clearly we are in a different place now due to the vaccine but we know immunity wanes after around six months, so the pace of the booster programme will be key in slowing the rate of hospital admissions. This seems to be ramping up now (223,000 booster jabs on 21/10 compared to 190,000 a week before), with public health campaigns and eligiability conditions being eased in the last few days. In my view this government will be extremely reluctant to impose restrictions on indoor meeting again but if daily hospitalisations tips over 1000 then they might be forced into it.
Continued case increases heading into the Holiday season makes me think there may be a push for intervention coming.

With vaccination rates at 90% in the UK, I think we are looking at 3 scenarios 1) a dangerous variant turning up that vaccines are not effective on, or the Delta variant infecting many who have been vaccinated. There have been 8 variants identified, all of them in 2020 - even the Delta variant was first identified in Nov 2020 (https://www.bmj.com/content/374/bmj.n1971) 8 variants in 2020. None so far in 2021. Youâ€™d expect at least 1 to turn up but it would also need to be worse than others and they typically take time to spread. (E.g. Delta took four or five months to reach the UK). 2) The Delta variant is largely hitting unvaccinated people for now in terms of ICU cases anyway in Switzerland which only has 50% vaccination rates. Infection rates in the UK are also dropping. So I think that is also unlikely. 3) low vaccination hotspotsâ€¦ I could not find evidence of this in the UK so I think this is again a small chance. Assumptions: * The restrictions will be imposed only if the healthcare system is close to its capacity * Currently the healthcare system is at ~20% of capacity and growing very slowly: https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/healthcare * Back to school and more indoor time in the winter will have a relatively minor impact on the number of cases * The uptake of the second dose of the vaccine will continue at a linear rate, growing from ~76% today to ~88% by the end of September. * The UK will start booster shots in September, which should help based on what we see in Israel * No new variant that is worse than Delta will become dominant by the end of December.
